div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definaitely engaged beforehand: Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monda.A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving inLondon at the very convenient hour of 4.56.p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fair is £22.9.11 Port Said to London vis Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leaves Suez for Aden and Bombay every WEdnesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.

div.head: THE STATE OF EUROPE
div.p: The conference of Algeciras has drawn attention to the possible assistance which Great Britain may render to France if events should happen to take an unfortunate turn. This goodwill which has sprung up in recent between France and England, of which President Loubet so felicitously indicated last week the origin and progress, is the sentiment accompanying a very important historical development. It indicates the instinctive recognition by both nations of Great Britain's peculiar function in the European economy. The Continent of Europe contains a number of nations and of great States more or less identical with them. These States, in virtue of the principle of their existence, which is that of the independence of each of them, reinforced in modern times and especially in the last hundred years by the principle of nationality, and necessarily in perpetual rivalry, which leads to groupings that vary from time to time. The general principle of the groupings has been, since the Sixteenth Century at any rate, that in proportion as one State increases in population, territory, and organization, and therefore in power, the others become apprehensive of its too great preponderance. Its great prosperity and strength begin to seem a menace to the independence of the others, and the growing State, in the consciousness of its developing power, is apt to expect its influence to become paramount and to attribute to itself a superiority hardly consistent with the fall autonomy of its neighbours. Such was the position at one time of the Germania Empire, at another of the Spanish Monarchy, afterwards of the French Monarchy, and subsequently of the first French Empire. In every case the expanding State found the maritime power of Great Britain an obstacle to the foil attainment of the sort of supremacy towards which it was impelled. There has, therefore, always been tendency for Great Britain to be regarded with special jealousy by the strongest Continental Power, and the consequence of that jealousy has always been to draw towards Great Britain the sympathy of those Continental States which were apprehensive of a preponderance dangerous to their free will. The difficult periods have been those of transition, when there has been a change in the relations of the Continental Powers. Thus Great Britain in tie Sixteenth Century found herself in opposition to the preponderance of Spain. The sentiment of opposition lasted long after the necessity was gone, and the tendency to co-operate with France was continued into the period when the real danger to the independence of States was from France rather than from Spain.

During the second half of the Nineteenth Century the great change that took place in Europe was the attainment of German unity, and the rise in Central Europe of a German S ate stronger in respect of population, territory, and organization than any of the other settled States, for Russia is still rather an Asiatic despotism than a European organised State. The event of the dose of the Nineteenth Century was the propagation in Germany of the theory that Great Britain with her maritime resources and her colonies and her Indian Empire was an obstacle to Germany's development. This propaganda, sedulously fostered by an influential party in Germany, was accompanied by a corresponding development of German sentiment. The event of the beginning of the Nineteenth Century has been the recog-nition in England of the political significance of this new German sentiment Germany has taken the place in the European system which was occupied in the Sixteenth Century by the Spanish Monarchy and in the Seventeenth by he French Monarchy. It is of the expansive purpose of Germany that her neighbours are apprehensive, and at the same time Germany has shown that she regards Great Britain as it was regarded by Philip II., by Louis XIV., and by Napoleon. The recognition of these foots has made dear to the other Continental States the true position of England, obscured for nearly a century They now see that England with her naval power is the balancing element in the European system, the one element which by its nature must be in sympathy with their independence and opposed to any designs which would menace it This is the fundamental fact, the instinctive recognition of which is the deep historical basis of the entente cordiale

div.head: THE SUCRERIES GO.
CONCORDAT GRANTED.
SATURDAY'S MEETING OF CREDITORS.
div.p: The creditors of the Société des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie o'Egypte met on Saturday after- noon at 3 o'clock. Judge Tack presided over the meeting, which was held at the Mixed Courts, assisted by MM. Zighara ana Chiarai-oli. To principal mere beta of the Cairo Bar were there with the Hon. A. J. Davey, M. Naas, and other members of the company.

At the opening of toe proceedings Me. Carton de Wiart informed the judge that alt the creditors had agreed to accept a slight modification on the proposals already submitted to the Court. M. Zighara then read a letter from Me. Courceiie, *ho protested most spiritedly against the gianting of the concordat preveuttf and demanded the prosecution of all the directors except the Hon. A. J. Davey.

However, as Me. Conroeile only represented 85 shares the majority swept his protest aside, end Me carton de W lart laid before the' Coart the minutes of the arrangement adopted as to the concordat with the signatures of the creditors, and with it the oonvcntiou of the Daira Sugar Compauy and the Suoiertes.
The voting followed, with this result : for the granting uf the cunoordat, 64,2x5 votes, representing L. E. 2,267,11s ; against, 199 votes, representing In E. 4
Tue yroce't verbal was signe i at 6 p. m. and the Sucreries Company opened a new chapter in its history. May it end happily.
The confirmation of the arrangement will take place on Saturday next

div.head: THE FRONTIER QUESTION.
WHERE HAVE THEY GONE ?
MYSTERIOUS DEPARTURE OF VESSELS.
div.p: Suez, Saturday.

Yesterday evening the Coast Guard cruiser Nour-el-Bahr sailed from Suez for an unknown destination, and was followed by the British cruiser Diana It is supposed that they have both gone up the Gulf of Akaba
The Akaba negotiations are officially stated to be proceeding most amicably, and a favorable solution of the frontier difficulty is anticipated within the next few days.
Naoum Bey 8hukair, of the Intelligence Department, has left for Sinai.

div.head: THE CAB STRIKE.
div.p: At the extraordinary meeting of the Alexandria Municipal Commission held on Saturday afternoon, it was decided to adopt the new cab tariff proposed by the andria committee appointed to deal with the question, but the proposed reduction of the tax imposed on oab8 was not agreed to. It is, bow ever, believed that the question of 'he tax will be farther discussed at the next municipal meeting, after the elections.

div.head: SAVOY DANCE.
div.p: On almost every occasion that we report the weekly Saturday evening's dance at the Savoy Hotel, we have to record a larger attendance than ever. Last Saturday, both dining-room and restaurant were filled to overflowing before the dance, and later in the evening an excep-tionally large number of residents came to swel the throng Dancing was, of course, considerably interfere 1 with as the ball room was uncomfortably crowded. but at the Savoy the larger crowd is the greater is the merriment, and the bumps and jostling's pass unheeded. Those who did not dance formed bridge parties or found chairs in the bill-room from which to watch the more youthful "tread the light fantastic," and the evening was enjoyed by one and all.

div.p: There is no diminution in the popularity of the Ghezireh Palace Hotel dances, and in spite of the extra one on Tuesday night, and that given by Mrs. Crofton on Wednesday, the rooms were filled again to their utmost on Thursday, on which evening alone close on four hundred people sat down to dinner in the hotel The usual dinner patties were in progress, many tables being laid for fourteen, sixteen, and eighteen guests, and among the hosts that evening were the Princes Louis and Antoine d'Orleans, who have returned to Cairo and taken up their quarters at Ghezireh, Sir James Blyth, Lady Keyser, Mrs. Hardy, Col. div.head: THE NATIONAL BANK
div.p: NO GOVERNOR APPOINTED
CHITTY BEY DECLINES THE POST.

The final selection of a new Governor of the National Bank of Egypt has still to be made, r for Chitty Bey has declined to accept the post. (After the Egyptian Government had agreed I to accept the selection of the board of directors d it was universally considered a foregone conclusion that the man whom they had chosen as their candidate would be appointed, and great was the amazement yesterday when it was known that the Director General of Customs o ha 1 intimated on Saturday afternoon that he r did not wish to accept the moat remunerative ii position in Egypt. The grounds on which Chitty Bey has based his refusual is that he has had I no experience of banking business and that he ii therefore does Dot consider that he can conscientiously accept the management of the E moat important banking concern in the country.

The reason for his selection as their candidate by the board of directors was that during his tenure of office as head of the greatest revenue-earning department in Egypt, he had shown great powers of administration and organization, and had in every way given proofs that he was possessed of the exceptional , abilities necessary for the guidance of the " bank. Another point which carried great weight with the board in making their choice was that he was a man of iron fixity of purpose, so that if he had made up his mind that a certain course was the right one, he would not deviate from it a hair's breadth notwithstanding what powerful influences might be brought to bear on him from the City.

The selection if Chitty Bey by the board represented the collective judgment of the most competent set of business men in Egypt, for the directors include the cream of he commercial and financial intelligence of the country. When such practical men as Boghos, Pacha Nubar, Baron Jacques de Menasce, Messrs. Aghion, Beyerle. Foster, de Tschndi, Cattaui, Suares, Zervudachi. Rollo, Ralli, Benachi, Salvago. Milton, and Pelazaeus decided to choose the Director-General of Customs so as their candidate, it was the highest tribute n that could be paid to his character and capacity.

At the interview which took place at the British Agency this day week between Lord Cromer and the directors, it was, however, decided that advice from London should be, sought, but on Friday morning the Egyptian Government announced that it would not g abide by this decision and was quite willing " to same to accept the candidate of the hoard. The waiver on the part of the Egyptian Government was tantamount to Lord Crmar's endorsement of the directors choice, and consequently everybody expected that a final decision would be arrived at when the board, met on Saturday afternoon. When it was known therefore yesterday morning that Chitty Bey had intimated his in willingness to accept the post all the qnidnoncery of Cairo and I Alexandria, who had already begun to speculate as to who would be the new head of the Customs, had to start on a fresh trail; but the search for motives which would induce he rennroiation of the most lucrative billet in Egypt nonplussed the boldest in a country whose prosperity engenders only the most sordid ideals.

Besides the magnificent salary, the L.E. 1 000 house allowance, and the annual remuneration of L E. 1,200 and L.E. 500 for the chairmanships of the Agriculture and Abyssinian Bank", there are other lucrative perquisites attached to the governorship. per example, after the 4 percent. to the shareholder, and 10 per cent, to the reserve on original profile, there is 10 percent. which goes to the board, of which the Governor first takes 25 per cent. L.E. 10,000 went to the board, he took LE 2,500 before the board came in, and then came in himself far the balance with the rest of the beard as a director. There are of course plenty of other legitimate ''pickings," even if extraneous directorships are henceforth prohibited, and the total annual income will come not far from L.B. 10,000.

When a man who is only, in receipt of LE. 1.500 a year refuses such a post on the grounds of lank of qualification when it is spontaneously offered to him, the imagination of the average person is at a loss to account for such a situation. Especially is this so in Egypt, where lack of experience has never been considered a disqualification and we have English officials placed in positions requiring most technical knowledge who have never received any professional training. For instance, one of the moat important posts in the Ministry of Justice is held by an official who has had no legal training whatsoever, and there are many other instances of favourites of fortune who have been jockeyed into positions without any qualifications.

The decision of Cbitty Bey is to he respectes'. He bolds that it is the primary and principal qualification of a banker to be well acquainted with banking, for it is a business which is not learned in a day, but needs antitude end apprenticeship like any other calling. Of banking Chitty Bey, from practical experience, admit-tedly knows nothing. Therefore, according to the Egyptian precedent, "lucus a non Iucendo," so usual in the bestowal of office in Egypt, the choice of the Government and of the board of directors has fallen upon him. To some his refusal of such a position will be incomprehensible. To others it will be explicable on the grounds that he lacks the most conspicuous mark of genius, the faculty of rising to the occasion. But to a minority his decision will be received with respect as a memorable sample of scrupulousness in a country where such a virtue is by no means conspicuous.
A meeting of the directors of the National Bank took place on Saturday afternoon, but no decision as to who should be selected as Governor was arrived at.

Our native contemporary "Al Moavad." in notifying Chitty Bey's action, remarks, "In any care he is one of the most useful Englishmen in Egypt, and Egyptians will be glad to see him always holding high positions, which bring him in touch with natives and where his service are useful to the country, whether he holds* post within or without the Government

div.head: INTERESTING BANQUET
div.p: AT SHEPHEARD'S
PRESS ENERTAIN OWEN BEY

The members of the Egyptian Press who recently visited the Sudan gave a dinner to Owen Bey on Saturday evening at 8hepheard's Hotel. ID spite of the fact that thirteen sat down to table owing to the absence of Naoum Bey 8hakair, the best of good spirits and cordiality prevailed, and the excellent menu provided speedily appeased the qualms of the most superstitious. The health of the guest of the evening was proposed by M. R. C. Canivet, up from Alexandria for the occasion. in one of those neatly felicitous after time speeches that few but a Frenchman can make. Dr. Paris Nimir made an admirable speech in the highest of Arabic. and Tadros Bey Shenouda also proposed the health of Owen Bey in eloquent terms.

In replying to the toasts in his honour Owen Bey, after thanking the Press for their good wishes, and complimenting them on the excellent articles that had been evoked by their visit, stated that every official, Egyptian, Sudanese, and British, would be glad to know that their work had been appreciated by disinterested observers, and that the members of the Press had thoroughly appreciated their visit to the Sudan and the efforts of the Sudan Government to make their visit a pleasant one.

More speeches followed. Mr. Tite, to whose kindness the Press are greatly indebted, replied in a few cordial words to a well-deserved toast by Dr. Nimr. Owen Bey prop sad "The Press" in a well oho«en and interesting speech, to which Mr. Hafiz Awad and Mr. Graves replied, the former pointing out that from the point of view of the Press the journey to Khartoum had been an unmixed benefit, bringing to/ether representatives of all shades of opinion who were united in their desire to advocate the good of Egypt. After thanking Owen Bey for his toast he called upon all present to drink to the proipen-y of the larger unity of the Nile Valley. It was not till after 11 p.m. that the party dispersed after a de-lightful evening.
The Press representatives present were Dr. Paris Nimr, Tadros Bey Shenouda, Hafiz Eff. Awad, Ali Bey Kamel, M. R Ganivet, the Count de Collalto, MM. Camel, Manse. Mansfield, di Pompeo and Graves.

div.head: EGYPTI AN INVESTMENT AND AGENCY, LIMITED.
div.p: The report f the diree'oraof this oomnany for the period ending 31stDecember, willbesnbm't- ted to the shareholders at the seoond "'di ry general meeting to be held at Wim-hes'er H nre, 0 d Broad Street, London, on Thursday next. The report and statement of accounts embrace the period since the incorporation of the company on the 9th of January, 1905, to the 81st Deoember. 190V The operations of the period under review have resulted in a nett profi' (without including any of the appreciation on investments referred to below) of £8 987 2 0. From this the directors have decided to write off one third of the preliminary expenses, amounting to £2.622 7 9, leaving a balanoe at oredit of profit and loss of £6,364 14 3. The directors recommend that this balance be dealt with as follows—In payment of a dividend of 10 per cent, free of income tax on the paid-op capital - f the company, £50,000, leaving £1,364 14 3 to be carried forward.

It has not been deemed necessary to set aside anything for reserve, as the investments made by the company represent an appreciation (which does not appear in the accounts submitted, of £10,000 on the basis of a valua-tion taken at practically the lowest point touched during the recent crisis on the Egyptian Bourse, since when prices have recovered considerably. The flotation of two important companies, the Building Lands of Egypt, Limited, and the Associated Cotton dinners of , Egypt, Limited, has been carried out and the success which has already attended the operations of these two companies has justified the expectations of the directors. A good return has been obtained from the | discounting of local paper, and a considerable extension of this branch of the company's business is in contemplation. The company's ' position has been kept liquid, as its investments are all readily realisable. Various proposals likely to prove sources of revenue are under consideration. A commercial branch has recently been inaugurated at Alexandria . for the conduct of an import and export business which will be prepared to act as agents for British and other firms who desire a responsible I and active agent in Egypt. Since the statutory ( meeting Major C. H. Villiers and Mr. F. Owen p have resigned their seats on the board. Sir Ernest Cable, during the greater part of his - absence in India, has been represented on the i board by Mr. C. Stewart Cox, who has recently 1 been elected to a seat on the |board, and the shareholders are asked to confirm his appoint-

div.head: CAIRO FESTIVITIES
div.p: BATTLE OF FLOWERS
AN IMMENSE GATHERING

Last night Cairo spent its time endeavoring get rid of the confetti collected during the f afternoon at the "Bataille de Fleurs.'' Ghezireh 1 still is laid deep in the rainbow-tinged snow- e storm that filled the air during the fray, and t there are but few out of the population who | did not add their quota to the display. Every arahieh in the place must have-been busy conveying the merry-makers across the river, and neither love nor money were able to secure a conveyance for the return journey.

Though the procession was advertised to commence at three o'olock, many people were in their seats soon after two, and a steady and ever-increasing stream of all sorts and conditions followed on their steps, till every seat in every stand and loge was filled, and the course was bordered on either side by a gaily-dressed crowd of men, women, and children, which almost put the decorations even 1 out of conceit with themselves. The confetti and flower sellers did a roaring trade, and when their stock was all run out, the enterprising Arab gathered up the fragments off the sandy paths, stuffed them again into discarded bags, and reaped a second harvest. From a strictly impartial view it cannot said that the display of decorated carriages could be compared with those to be seen on the Riviera, or indeed anywhere in France during the carnival season, and as a matter of fact there were many who said the display, was not up to the avenge for Cairo, and was inferior even to that of last year. The most, beautiful carriage, and it really was a work of art, was that belonging to Omar Bey Sultan. It represented a huge basket of pure white, with a high arched handle from, which depended long streamers of snowy chiffon. Both handle and basket and its stand were adorned with white flowers, and on it were perched a crowd of white-feathered, doves. The horses, too, were white, and so also was the harness with silver mountings. The coachman, beside whom stood the Bey, was also in white, and the sayces, too, were robed immaculately and carried white and flower- bedecked wands in their hands. It was not surprising that this oarriage obtained the pig d'honneur, a handsome silver cup, and M. Ferdinand de Martino gained the grandprix for his motor decorated with wreaths of violets and white flowers. Another carriage, drawn by two horses, was transformed into a veritable kiosk of flowers wherein was enshrined a dainty lady with two charming children in fairy like attire; another motor oar, which gained the second prize and was owned by M. Alexander Comanos, was transformed into the likeness of a scarlet dahabieh wreathed about with flowers, and two tiny children in a gaily- decorated oar drawn by a diminutive donkey ware overcome with pride when presented with a prize banneret. 0 her prizes ware awarded to the three ladies bearing flower-decked' sunshades (Mmea. Z *her, Beriketti, and Innis), I perhaps the prettiest being one with large transparent medallions encircled with dainty wreaths of lilies of the valley, the fragile hat of the Wwearer being made to coreespond

In the procession were many other carriages more or less decorated, and many people preferred spending their time moving round and round the course to remaining in the stands, and considering the crowd of pedestrians and vehicles it was wonderful that the afternoon passed without mishaps. As for the spirit of carnival, it was there with all its accustomed accessories. The air was filled with confetti and flowers and merry battles ware fought at every corner and ail along the line. Carriages were entangled wtth paper serpentines, while hats and pretty frocks, to say nothing of the garments of the sterner sex, were soon decorated and bespangled with the multicoloured particles

The fun ran riot till confetti bags were finished and the spirits of the throwers exhausted. With dusty throats and spent energies the worn out folk streamed back to the Ghezireh Palace Hotel, where every available nook and cranny was filled with eager tea drinkers. The road back to Cairo was a long procession of vehicles following all the same direction, and though the unfortunate wayfarers had a long and dusty tramp home, the carriage folk did not gain in point of time.

div.head: OPERA HOUSE FLOODED
div.p: EMPLOYER'S STRANGE FREAK
SATURDAY'S PERFORANCE OFF.

The Cairo Opera House was flooded on Saturday night—not by a thunderstorm but by internal irrigation, the work of an ingenious employ who, doubtless for curiosity's sake, turned on the fire tape which are designed to play on the stage in case of fire. The streams that descended on the stage should have satisfied and reassured him or any who doubted the value of the precautions now taken against fire, but their volume also alarmed him to such a degree that, paralyzed with tenor, he forgot to turn off the fire main. The scenery, the stage, the orchestra, and many of he properties were drenched, the electrical installation was injured, and the management could only send a frantic appeal to the Ministry of Public Works, who came, saw, and estimated the damages. Consequently there was no performance on Saturday night Iris gave place to Beidckt, and Cairo bad something to talk of.

div.head: OBITUARY
div.p: We regret to learn of the death, which took place at an early hoar this morning, of Mr. Hans von Tschudi, son of Mr. C. von Tschndi, head of the firm of Messrs. Plants & Co., of our town. Deceased was only 20 years of age, and died after a short illness. The funeral will take place to-morrow morning at 9 o'clock from the Deaconesses' Hospital, Mohrrem Bey. We beg to tender nor sincere sympathies with Mr. and Mrs. von Tschudi in their cruel bereavement

div.head:
THE FRENCH PRESIDENCY.
M. FALLIERES ASSUMES OFFICE

div.p: M. Loubet received the Diplomatic Corps in a formal farewell audience. Count Tornielli, the Italian Ambassador, paid a warm tribute of praise to M. Lonbet's pacifica tory influence in international affairs. M. Lonbet, in answering, landed the spirit in spiring the diplomatic corps which facilitated his efforts.
(Reuter)

The Corps Diplomatique took leave of M. Loubet, stating that they would bear an unchanging souvenir of him. M. Loubet thanked them and remarked on the increasing authority of ideas of right and international solidarity.
Havas

M. Loubet, in the afternoon, vacated the Elysde after formally transmitting the powers to M. Fallibres in the presence of the Presidents of the Chamber and Senate and the Minister. M. Loubet expressed his gratitude for their co-operation to the two Assemblies daring his presidency. M. Failures replied that he would strive to follow M. Loubet's example and appealed likewise for co-operation to Parlia meat M. Loubet, accompanied by M. Failures and M. Rouvier, then proceeded to his private residence.
(Reuter)

M. Failures has taken possession of the Elysle. M. Loubet welcomed him, and after- wards thanked the Ministers, the Senators, and the Deputies for their co-operation. M. Fallibres replied stating that he would do his ntaseefe to imitate M. Loubet, and that he would work for the greatness of the country.
M. Fallieres conducted M. Loubet to his new Rhode.
M. Failures has asked the Cabinet to remain in power.
Havas

div.head:
THE POPE AND FRANCE
ENCYCLICAL TO FRENCH CLERGY

div.p: The Papal encyclical to the French clergy and people strongly condemns the law separating the Church from the State.
An encyclical to the French clergy energetically protests against the' separation' of the Church from the State. 'The Pope will in due time send instructions as to the conduct they are to follow.
Havus

div.head:
KING CHRISTIAN'S FUNERAL
THE ROYAL MOURNERS

div.p: The Emperor William has arrived here. The Kings of Denmark, Greece, and Norway welcomed him on board a man of-war.

The funeral took place at 2 in the afternoon at Roskilde. The Royal mourners arrived by train and drove to the Cathedral, where a solemn service took place. King Christian's remains were deposited in a sarcophagus and the mourners returned to Copenhagen.
(Reuter)

div.head:
MISS ROOSEVELT MARRIED
IMMENSE NUMBER OF PRESENTS

div.p: Miss Alice Roosevelt was married to-day to Mr. Nicholas Longworth. There were 1,000 guests and enormous crowds. The newly-married couple received an immense number of costly presents.
(Reuter)
Lord de Clifford has married Miss Eva Carrington, a "Gibson Girl" at the Aldwych Theatre.
(Reuter)
The strike has ended, the man's demands having been granted.
(Reuter)

At a Labour demonstration at Queen's Hall, Mr. Keir Hardie repudiated the ide> of an understanding with the tariff reformers. It is believed that the Labour Party will become more and more Socialist in tendency.
(Reuter)
Association. Cambridge beat Oxford by 3 to 1. England beat Ireland by 5 to nil.

div.head:
A MOROCCO INCIDENT
FRENCH STEAMER SHELLED

div.p: A curious incident took place at Marchica, near Melilla, where the French have established a factory. The Moorish cruiser Turki shelled and pursued the French steamer Zenith, which was calling at Marchica, The Pretender's artillery ashore shelled the Turki. The French cruiser Lalande intervened and ordered the Zenith to return here.
(Reuter)
It seems clear that the Zenith was landing arms and munitions for the Pretender. The Lalande's interference consequently raises a difficult question.
(Reuter)
M. de Radowitz formally proposed to M. Revoil to entrust the policing of Morocco to the Sultan under international control, bat this scheme is entirely unacceptable to France
(Reuter)
France has replied in a verbal note to the German proposal agreeing to entrust the police force to the Sultan provided that the officers are French and Spanish
(Reuter)
The Franco Russian commercial treaty has been passed by the Senate.
(Reuter)

div.head:
DISTRESS IN POLAND
SPIRIT STORES PILLAGED

div.p: Extreme distress prevails in Poland in con- sequence of strikes and disturbances. Starving people are attacking and pillaging spirit stores. The Government is endeavouring to arrange with the banks here to tide over the commercial crisis
(Reuter)
Generals Kuropatkin and Bitianoff have been recalled from Manchuria
(Reuter)
By the Tsar's directions General Linievitch yesterday transferred the command of the troops to General Grodekoff
(Reuter)
the dissolution of Parliament is announced to take place on Monday
(Havas)

(Reuter)

(Reuter)

div.head: ALLEGED ASSOUAN BALL INCIDENT
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

Dear Sir,—Had I realised, when, in a frivolous mood, I sent you my impressions of the Cataract Hotel fancy dre?8 hall, that any remarks could be seized upon by an ill-bred person and made the subject-matter of an offensive letter, I should never have penned those lines at all.

The lady in question, in sheer light-hearted- ness, donned a dragoman's costume in ignorance of the evil effects her action would have on the native mind; and any remarks were meant to be a gentle rebuke for an action which I felt sure the toiler knowledge of the servant mind would have prevented.
The query mark after the word "lady" in the letter of a "Lover of Womanly Women" is the result of the workings of a puerile brain.
All those who have the privilege of knowing this lady, are deeply conscious of an honour which "A Lover of Womanly Women" could never experience.
As the writer of the critique in question I should be most happy to meet 'A Lover of Womanly Women" at any time she suggests.— Yours, etc.,
"A HATER OF LACK OF BREEDING"
POST OFFICE, Assouan, February 15.

div.head: EGYPT'S LATEST
CONTRIBUTIONS TO SCIENCE.
div.p: THE MUMMIED BEAST.
BY HENRY DE VARIGNY
The EMbalming of Animals

Some seventy centuries ago the Egyptians began to embalm the dead. Viewing their work with delighted satisfaction—like the late lamented Pencil, who admired even the backs of his pictures—they kept on with it, and embalmed everything that could by hook or crook be embalmed. The irreverent Egyptologist who digs the soil of the old Nile valley finds it honeycombed with the graves of kings, queens, priests, dignitaries, and folk of low degree, while underground Egypt has yielded up its millions and even billions of millions animals. Many of them found a practical use as fertilizers.

From time to time it has occurred to naturalists that these mummied animals would repay study, and though many of the deposits have been exhausted, M. Maspero succeeded in securing remnants of them, and in handing the remnants over to competent naturalists. Hence the beautiful book which MM. Lortet and Gaillard of Lyons have brought out under the title, "La Faune Momifiee de l'Ancienne Egypte."

I have said that the Egyptians embalmed almost everything, and, as a matter of literal fact, their animal burying-grounds contain monkeys, dogs, jackals, cats, shrewmice, rats, cattle, antelope, gazelles, sheep, wild sheep and goats, to say nothing of birds— among them the ibis—and such reptiles as the serpent and the crocodile, with a plentiful supply of fi h, mollusks and injects. Each species boasts countless examples

From all this we may extract at least a respectable amount of philosophy. When Napoleon invaded Egypt, Jomard propounded an interesting problem in his "Description de l'Egypte " Said Jomard: "These various mummies and fragments of animals will one day enable naturalists to tell what it species inhabited Egypt during a very rem ate period. Indeed, there is no other way of knowing whether the animals that now thrive in Egypt are the same as those that throve three centuries ago, or to establish the grave question as to the invariability of essential or specific forms throughout the ages." To the question put by Jomard, the Lyons naturalists give categorical reply. The species embalmed twenty, thirty, or even seventy centuries ago have not changed in the least. The animals of modern Egypt are the animals of ancient Egypt

div.head: Evolution
div.p: Is this equivalent to saying that evolution is a humbug ? Not at all. For every naturalist can name species that have remained unchan-ged, not merely for seventy centariei, bat for thousands of centuries. Some of these are brachiopods, whose origin dates from the most ancient period of life upon the globe. On the other hand, evolution doesn't depend in the least upon proving tint species have changed. Such necessity exists solely when environment changes, or when an animal eaters a new environment. An animal adapted to its environ- ment changes only when the environment changes. Now in Egypt the environment has long been what it is to-day, and we should have no reason to expect to find the animals of present-day Egypt at all different from their ancestors of sixty or seventy centuries ago. And they certainly are not. Far from militating against the theory of evolution, the study of the mummied animals of Egypt precisely fulfil the evolutionist's expectations and predictions. I need not dwell further upon this highly important fact ; let ns pass now to an examination of certain secondary facts brought out by the Lyons naturalists. We shall find them instructive

div.head: The Cat
div.p: Everyone knows that Egypt worshipped the Cat. The cat,

"Le divin quadruple aux pupilles etroite," as Taine called her, was a sacred animal, the emblem of the goddess Sekhet or Best, who had a temple at Bubastes. Mummied cats abound in Egypt. The necropolis of Stabl- Antar, half a mile long, is packed with them. Bat biology here notes an interesting fact; the Egyptians had two kinds of cat. The one that ] was most frequently embalmed (and therefore doubtless the most highly venerated) was the magnificent gloved cat, Felis maniculata, which still exists in a wild state in all parts of the country. The other was a domesticated variety of that species. It would be immensely interesting, I may say in passing, to make a special study of the oat of the Egyptian necropoles in documents of known date, so as to learn to what degree and with what speed the cat became transformed when she left her free life and became domesticated. But this much, in any case, is worthy of comment: there is DO longer in Egypt a fall-blooded example of the domesticated gloved cat. The breed is pore only when wild.

The gloved cat had evidently its share in producing our own domesticated cat, as had also very possibly—the booted which is now found in North Africa, bat which is common enough in Europe during the Quaternary period. The "bracelets" on the torelegs of our striped cat are plainly those of the gloved cat ; and in Spain it is beyond question that the domestic cat is descended from the gloved variety. So far as appearances go, we might conclude that the Egyptians had a cat that has since disappeared, or that they had an imported cat; in reality the cat was there all the while, only enjoying a life of freedom

div.head: The Ibis
div.p: With the ibis the case is wholly different. The ibis was sacred to Isis ; it personified the Nile Valley ; it was the emblem of Egypt in the days when Toth, the god of learning and medicine, personified the intellect. But Hero- dotus attributes two ibises to Egypt; a black one, which was a great destroyer of serpents, and a white one, which was a domesticated bird. When the Nile rose, then came countless it ibises, and the people credited them with what was really the work of the river. But no black ibis exists ; what now becomes of Herodotus's veracity! Thanks to science, it gets its defence; the philologists explain that the Damn applied to the black ibis is that of another species, which exists to-day, and certain mummied ibises are found to be this very bird. And now someone will ask about the white ibis, far the white ibis has undeniably vanished from Egypt. And yet it was living there a century ago • Savigny saw several specimens of it in the Delta. Some were observed even as late as 1877, and it still survives in Ethiopia. Perhaps Egypt does not attract it so effectually as formerly. At any rate the difficulty need not embarrass us.

div.head: The Sheep
div.p: Another point, however, involves really serious difficulties, which make MM. Lortet and Gaillaid's explanation of it only the more interesting. It concerns sheep, of which the Egyptians embalmed two varieties—the Qvis Platycera and the longipes. Where did they get them! Such a question as this is full of interest for historians of civilization and of humanity in general. It was at first supposed that the longipes came from Asia. Asiatic importations were long in fashion—man was thought to have come from Asia, and so were animals and plants; theology, certain philosophies, and a lot of legends agreed in making Asia the cradle of every living creature that WAS at all worth while. Now MM. Lortet and Gaillard beg leave to observe that there are serious reasons for believing that the sheep in question (and many other animals, for that matter) didn't originate in Asia, but rather in the very part of Africa where they are to-day. Pray observe that the prehistoric burial places of Egypt contain this sheep and only this sheep. On the other band, a very ancient document —it dates from the thirteenth dynasty—tells ns that King Snefron ravaged the Upper Nile and brought home seven thousand Negroes and 200,000 cattle and sheep. Already the inferior races had begun to be looted by the strong ; Egypt had witnessed a prelude to the "Congnism"—sit venia verbo—of our own day. No doubt it was from the Sudan that pre- historic man originally got the lengipes sheep, which had perhaps been more widely indigenous in the Nile Valley before men became numerous. I And fi ally it is to be noted that the sheep in question doesn't bear a foreign name. Its thoroughly Egyptian name is "ba." Thus every- thing goes to show that the animal didn't come from Asia or from any far-off country, bat was a native of Egypt.

As regards the other variety, it's quite a different story. Ira name is "sau"—strongly suggestive of Asia, particularly of Assyria, Arabia, and Palestine. Mummied specimens in Egypt date solely from the first dynasty, and probably we should find this variety still living in Asia if we searched diligently enough. Let us render unto Asia the things that are Asia's and unto Africa the things that are Africa's

div.head: Cattle
div.p: The study of mummied cattle is no less significant. The Egyptian cow was believed to have been an importation from Asia—probably from Syria. but the debris of ancient Egypt afford no remains of this Asiatic variety ; they are found only at a very recent period.

On the other hand, the ancient Egyptians possessed a beautiful breed of cattle that no longer exists. Where did it go to? Where did it come from? In Egypt it is evidently extinct. But it exists elsewhere in profuse abundance, from Khartoum to the Great Lakes. In other words, the animal the ancient Egyptians embalmed was none other than the zebu, droves of which exist to-day on the plains along the Upper Nile. It was imported into Egypt dozens of centuries ago: it dwindled and died off as the result of some sort of epizootic, and it was replaced by an Asiatic breed, which was quite possibly brought to Egypt by some returning conquerer. Again we are forced to credit Africa with a product of Africa.

div.head: The Origin of Man
div.p: In other directions, however, one may generalize, and that is what MM. Lortet and Gaillard do so pretty fearlessly when they leave the subject of beasts and turn to that of men. It is folly, say they to suppose that the African race originated in Asia. Like his sheep and his cattle, he originated in Africa The flint implements scattered by the billion along the shores of the Nile cannot possibly be regarded as having belonged to vanished negroid tribes; they simply belonged to the oldest of ancient Egyptians. All the skulls that have been un- earthed show themselves to be those of ancient Egyptians and not those of prehistoric men. The modern Egyptians are descendants of the ancient Egyptians, who were descendants of prehistoric Africans, not, of prehistoric Asiatics.

So the mummies don't teach us anything about the origin of man. That subject has al- ready been fairly exhaustively discussed, though MM. Lortet and Gaillard add further support to the conclusion reached by the anthropologists.

div.head: Hornless Cattle
div.p: The cattle give us further information of great value, for tbeir mummies prove that the Egyptians bad succeeded in breeding a race of cattle without horns. Handers cattle, so eagerly sought for by modern breeders, had already been obtained by the -Egyptians. How? No- body knows. Nevertheless, they had them, and they gave them a distinctive name. Apparently they didn't make them work, hot treated them as a mere curiosity. And yet they were by no means rare. A single district had 2 0 hornless cattle as over against 835 homed ones. These cattle were born without horns ; they had not been artificially dehorned. Moreover, we have Stanley's word for it that in the neighbourhood of the African lakes one finds hornless cattle enough like those of the Angus, Suffolk and Iceland breeds. Probably those races, like that possessed by the Egyptians, sprang from exceptional individuals, born with- out horns and used for the purpose of securing a hornless breed. In other words, the Egyptians practised selection and employed it intelligently long before European breeders ever thought of so doing, which certainly reflects credit en the Egyptian brain and affords an interesting topic for the historian of their civilization to descant upon.

div.head: Animal Pathology
div.p: The naturalist, the anthropologist and the historian will find the book of MM. Lortet and Gaillard fail of valuable material, and so will the pathologist, for among the mummied animals of Egypt are specimens that throw light upon animal pathology forty, fifty and even sixty centuries ago. In some oases one can diagnose the diseases the beasts died of. For instance, the ape fell victim to tuberculosis then as now. The great malady of modern times existed in the Nile Valley thousands of years ago, and it doubtless killed men as well as monkey*. But it is likely that the ape came from a remote equatorial country and contracted tuberculosis when brought to a cooler region. This is what happens to all the monkeys transplanted to our so called temperate climate. Nil sub sole novum. (Translated from the "Temps".;

div.head: THE REAL FASHODA
div.p: MARCHAND'S CURIOUS SELECTION OF
A CAMP

Under the heading "To Equatorial!" Mr. Andrew Balfour gives a realistic picture of Fashoda as it is now, which cannot but awaken lively sympathy with the misguided Colonel Marchand, who most have been devoutly thankful when Lord Kitchener arranged for his departure.

The writer calls it a "fever-stricken hole, perched in all the ugliness of red brick on a bank surrounded the greater part of the year by vile and stinking morasses, facing a sluggish backwater, lined by hideous black mod, and an island which is more or less swamp.

"Here the mosquito is triumphant. Long, sooty females flock to feed on ns : the shrill ping of the flying gnat torments the ear- Fashoda had its little romance, but that is gone with its name, and there is not much to be said for the spot to which the eyes of Europe were once turned."

div.head: AN ENGLISH MOHAMEDAN'S OATH.
div.p: In a case beard at the Old Bailey last week, in which a young Englishwoman named Margaret True Prebble, the wife of a corporal in the Army Service Corps, was charged with obtaining goods from West-end firms by representing herself as Ladv Muriel Paget and other persons of wealth and position, the prisoner, when about to give evidence in defence, was sworn upon the Old Testament as a Jewess. After she had been in the witness-box for some time the Judge, on being consulted by the usher, asked her what religion she pro- fessed. Prisoner replied : I joined the Mohamedans in 1893, though I still believe in the old Bible.
After discussion it was decided that prisoner most be re-sworn in the Mohamedan fashion.

An usher was dispatched to find a Koran, and in the meantime prisoner took off her shoes which she placed in front of her. On the Koran being produced, prisoner, under the direction of the judge, held the book in her left hand, with her right band across her forehead. Thrice she bowed her head in a profound salaam until her forehead touched the book, while the usher repeated the adjuration to speak the truth. She did this Solemnly with a set face, but the proceeding occasioned considerable amusement. Then she replaced her boots and faced counsel.
At the adjourned hearing prisoner was found guilty, and sentenced to eighteen monlths'* hard labour

div.head: THE SIMPLE LIFE
div.p: A curious interest attaches to the admission of a man named Sandy Sands to Leicester Infirmary

Eighteen years ago he lost his wife, to whom he was strongly attached, and made a vow never to sleep on a bed or to wash himself for twenty years. Ever since be has led the simple life, sleeping in barns and stables, and subsisting on a penny a day, his fare being dry bread j with the occasional luxury of batter. He would probably have carried out his vow had he Dot been bitten by a dog. The wound festering, he was unable to move, and was in danger of starving when the police removed him. He had first to undergo no fewer than five baths, the strongest disinfectant soaps being need.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Aujmrdhui à midi et demis)
div.p: Le marché, qu'on s'attendait à voir faible aujourd'hui, a été au contraire ferme et animé
Seules les Banques accusent une légè-e réaction, l'Agricole à 10 1/8 et la National Bank à 27 13 16 vendeurs
Le Comptoir s'avance à 5 9/16 et la part de fondateurs Estâtes à 8 1/16 acheteurs
Par contre l'Investment réactionne à 1 "/32 vendears et la Brasserie des Pyram'des à 127 la privilégiée et 67 la dividende.
De 13 11/16 la Nungovioh monte à 13 3/4
Les Suc'eries accusent une reprise sensible de 28 à 36 francs
Tandis que l'action Khédivial Mail fléchit de 4 5/8 à 4 9/16. l'Ordinary monte de 27 à 31.
En revanche, la part de fondateurs Eaux du Caire perd 9 francs à 285
Le reste de la cote demeure ferme aux prix antérieurs

Ce maintien des cours est dû à la bonne impression produite par la dépêohe Reuter de ce matin, mais cette agence nous a servi jusqu'ici des nouvelles si pessimistes sur la conférence, qu'il est bon d'attendre la fin dès pourparlers pour émettre une opinion. Quant là nom, nous n'avons pas un instant douté du (résultat final de la conférence mais on ignore encore la durée que prendront les déhbérations et si la phase critique actuelle n'inflaera pas sur le marché.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITQUES
div.p: A Londres, le Consolidé anglais et l'Unifiée sont restés invariés hier à 90 3/4 et 105 1/4.La National Bank et la Daïra Sanieh ont fléchi de 1/8 à 27 3/8 et 17 7/8. L'Agricole est demeurée inchangée 10 1/8
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien est renseignée en hausse de 4 francs a 808 et la Banque d'Athènes en reprise de 1 franc à 144.
Notre marché des valeurs a été ce matin fort animé, avec tendance très ferme et des cours en reprise sur la plupart des valeurs.

La National Bank a ouvert à 27 5/8 laotien ancienne pour clôturer a 27 >3/16—7/8; l'action nouvelle est à 26 7/8—15/16. L'Agricole s'est inscrite à 10 3/16 l'action ancienne et 9 11/) 6 la nouvel>e. La Banque d'Athènes est à 145. La Cassa di Sconto est remontée à 197. l'action ancienne et 193 la nouvelle. Le Comptoir Financier a avancé à 5 9/16
L'action Crédit Foncier a progressé à 810
Toujours mouvementées, les parts de jouissance Eaux du Usure ont ouvent à 295 pour clôturer à 289
Sur de nombreux achats, la Brasserie des Pyramides a atteint jusqu'à 185, gagnant 15 francs sur le cours de la veille, pour clôturer à 129 ; la part de dividende a haussé de 60 a 70.
L'Agricole du N il a progressé à 263. Les Wardan fis ta te sont revenus à 7 $ ; les Laud Allotment à 311/16 et leurs parts de fondateur à 92

Poursuivant leur mouvement ascensionnel, les dividendes Tramways d'Alexandrie ont avancé jusqu'à 83s pour clôturer à 325. Les ordinaires Khédivial Mail ont gagné près de 3 sh. à 27.6. Les Ramleh ont fléchi à b 7/8.
Le groupe des Hôtels a été calme.

Parmi 168 petites valeurs, on a remarqué de très bons acheteurs en parts de fondateur Egyptien Estates, qui out haussé d'une demi- livre à 7 J/4. Il y a lieu de prévoir des cours encore plus élevés, étant donné l'excellent mouvement d'affaires fait par cette Société. Les actions Western Egypt (Oasis) ont également monté à 1 3/32 acheteurs.
Les Salt sont revenus à 23 sh. 9 et les Markets ont progressé à 25 sh.

Bien qu'elle n'ait pas été encore annoncée officiellement, la nomination de Chitty bey, directeur-général des douanes au poste de gouverneur de la National Bank of Egypt, peut être considérée comme positive.

On annonce d'Alexandrie que l'Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Co. vient d'acheter l'abadieh du comte Zizinia, sise près d'Atfeh, sur les borda du canal Mahmoudieh. Il s'agit d'une superficie de 660 feddans.
L'acquisition a été faite pour L.E 40 ?00, soit au prix avantageux d'environ L.E. 61 le feddan
Ce terrain est situé dans le voisinage de ceux que la Société a achetés récemment.

La Menzaleh Canal and Navigation Co. se propose d établir très prochainement OD service par steamers entre Matarieh et Karponty (Port-Saïd), en attendant l'ouverture de la ligne entre Port-Saïd et Mansourab.

On ajoute que la Société est en négociations avec le gouvernement pour se substituer aux cheikhs locaux comme agent dans la vente du poisson du lao de Matarieh, afin de protèger les intérêts des pêcheurs
La Compagnie a fait récemment l'acquisition a Matarieh de plusieurs lots de terrains à bâtir qui promettent un profit considérable
L' assemblée générale de L'Egyptian Improvements Corporation aura lieu lundi prochain, 19 février, à 3 h. 30 p.m., au Grand Continental Hôtel
Les cours du cotou en Amérique sont en légère reprise. Le Mai et l'Octobre ont gagné hier 3 pointa respectivement. Le disponible est resté inchangé à 11. 25.
Lei arrivages ont été de 21,000 balles poutre 14,000
Le marché de Liverpool est plus ou moins stationnaire.
Ici, le Mars a ouvert, ce matin, à 181/16 pour clôturer à 17 31/32.

MM. H. de Vrie8 et Boutigny, agents de change, se chargent d9 l'exécution de tons ordre* Bourse (valeurs et marchandises) eur les marchés de Londres, Paris, Bruxelles, An vers, Liverpool et New-York. La Circulaire quo- ti tienne de la maison est envoyée sur demande.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the mostdelightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.
World-wide reputation.
P: Sohnack, Proprietor
Level Wooded Walks.

div.head: LIDO (VENICE) LIDO
div.p: From Vernon or Lido, 12 min by steamboat. Climatic Station and Sea Baths, with Chinesitherapic Institute. Express between the station and Lido for the hotels.

div.head: BAGNI LIDO
div.p: The most important bathing station in Italy. ____ Restaurant and Terrace on the sea. Hydrotherapic institute. Concerts daily, frequented by the highest classes of society.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL DES BAINS.
div.p: Adjoining the sea. First-class hotel with dependencies & chalets. 200 rooms & saloons. Electric light. Aqueduct. Every modern comfort. Delightful residence, without any mosquitos.

div.head: THE GRAND HOTEL LIDO.
div.p: Hotel with its dependencies (Swiss Hotel), in the most delightful situation of the Lido at the landing place, five minutes walk from the bathing place. Wonderful view of the Legune of Venice. Room from 3 lire, with board from 8.50 per day. No mosquitos. Very dry and safe air.
Address- SOCIETE BACHI, LIDO, VENICE, ITALY.

div.head: St. Moritz (Engadine) Switzerland. The Grand Hotel St. Moritz.
div.p: A new first class hotel with every modern convenience.
Address all inquiries to THE MANAGER.

div.head: LAKE OF COMO (Cernobble.) GRAND HOTEL VILLA D'ESTE
div.p: First-class hotel, finest situation on the Lake. Immense park and garden. Moderate charges. Omnibus at Como station.
T. Domben, Manager.

div.head: COMO "PLINIUS" GRAND HOTEL,
div.p: On the border of the Lake with beautfiul Garden and large Terraces. Magnificent Palace, built for the purpose of an Hotel, with the most complete comfort. Opened March, 1899. Very reasonable prices. English church.
Proprietor: J. De Glacomi, Manager of Gd. Hotel Neues Stahibad, St. Moritz, Engadine, Switzerland.
Manager: C. Scrobbi, of Neues Stahibad, St. Moritz.

div.head: LUGANO (Lake of Lugane) GRAND HOTEL METROPOLE ET MONOPOLE.
div.p: STRICTLY FIRST CLASS.

Also of the GRAND HOTEL, LUGANO.

div.head: LOCARNO THE GRAND HOTEL.
div.p: OPEN ALL THE YEAR.

Strictly first class. Every modern comfort. Terminus of the St. Gothard Railway. Magnificent winter and spring Resort. Best stopping place on the Italian lakes. Beautiful walks excursion English Chruch. Tennis and Golf. Central Heating.

div.head: LUCERNE HOTEL DE L'EUROPE
div.p: Comfortable family hotel, charmingly situated, known for its quietness, Extensive view of Lake and Mountain scenery. Newly furnished, every modern comfort, lift, electric light, throughout, grand hall and covered terraces, beautiful garden, table d'Hotel at small tables, moderate terms.
New proprietors, Blorn Bros.

div.head: Hotel TIVOLI pension.
div.p: Beautiful situation overlooking the Lake.
FIRST CLASS.
Every modern comfort
Moderate charges.

div.head: INNSBRUCK (Tyrol) CARL KAISER'S PENSION-HOTEL
div.p: Splendid situation, overlooking river and valley, surrounded by fruit, conifer and rose gardens, modern comforts and home-like, Library, English and American papers, baths, carriages, good Table and sanitary arrangements.

Specially suitable for those requiring rest, quietness, and change of air. Capital headquarters for excursions. Post telegraph, telephone, dark room, terms moderate for either short or long stay. English spoken. Apply for prospectus.

div.p: JUNGFRAUBLICK.

Central heating. Every modern comfort.

div.p: The newesty and most up-to-date, thoroughly First Class and replete with every modern comfort.
ELECRTIC LIGHT, CENTRAL HEATING, PRIVATE BATHS.

div.p: The most comfortable first class family hotel.
EVERY MODERN COMFORT.
Berthod Brothers Proprietors.

div.head: ATHENS HOTEL DE LA GRANDE BRETAGNE
div.p: Special Office in the Hotel for Railway and Steamship
Tickets: also Post Office.
E. Lampsa, proprietor.

div.head: TOURIST AGENCY. POLEMY BROS., ATHENS.
div.p: 2. Philellenic Street (corner of Constitution Square), Conducted Tours for visiting Greece, Ionian Islands, Islands of the Archipelago, Asia Minor, Turkey, Palestine and Egypt.

div.head: CORFU GRAND HOTEL D'ANGLETERRE ET BELLE VENISE
div.p: Only first-class Hotel in Corfu with magnificent Garden. Fashionable modern Family Hotel. View of the Sea and lovely landscapes. Quietest, healthiest, and highest situation. Is the only Hotel situation in the highest part of Corfu.
Jean Garru and Freen, Proprietors.
